title: Allergies
content:
To defend itself against the allergen, your body produces antibodies called immunoglobulin E (IgE). These antibodies cause certain cells in your body to release chemicals (eg, histamine) into your bloodstream in an attempt to fight off the invader.
The release of these chemicals causes an allergic reaction. Symptoms vary depending on the part of your body that's affected, but can include sneezing, watery eyes, itching, rash and raised weals ([hives](https://healthify.nz/health-a-z/h/hives "Hives")) on your skin. An extreme allergic reaction can be life-threatening and needs immediate treatment. This is called[anaphylaxis](https://healthify.nz/health-a-z/a/anaphylaxis "Anaphylaxis").
